questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. The patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia suddenly. Which of the following is the most likely image of his capnography?
questions.solution: Ans. C.

questions.text: You are preparing to intubate a patient in the operating room. As part of your preoperative assessment, you perform a Mallampati examination to assess the patient's airway. Identify the class from the image shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Mallampati Class III

questions.text: A large cohort study is conducted to assess the association between smoking and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus among middie-aged men. During 10 years of follow-up, smokers have 5 times the risk of esophageal carcinoma compared to non-smokers (relative risk 5.0, 95% confidence interval = 2.9-7.1). According to the study results, what percentage of squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus in smokers can be attributed to smoking?
questions.solution: Ans. D. 80%

  1. Prescriptive screening - Secondary

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the OPD due to recurrent, painful skin lesions in the right axilla for the past 6 months. The patient has no other medical history and takes no medication. Examination is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Obstruction of folliculopilosebaceous units

questions.solution: Ans. A. Decreases need of intubation

questions.solution: Ans. B. 1-b,2-a, 3-d,4-c

choices.text: Random misclassification bias

questions.text: A large prospective study evaluates the relationship between alcohol consumption and breast cancer. A total of 4000 middle-aged women are enrolled in the study through a random selection of residential addresses. Daily alcohol consumption and breast cancer incidence are assessed through the use of periodic questionnaires. On five-year follow-up, the investigators report the association between alcohol consumption and breast cancer as a relative risk of 1.32 (95% confidence interval = 0.90-1.85); 800 subjects were lost to follow-up by the end of the study, the majority of whom were moderate to heavy alcohol consumers. According to this information, which of the following biases is most likely to be present and may have affected the results?
questions.solution: ﻿﻿Ans. D. Selection bias

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for difficulty breathing and a productive cough. He has a past medical history of recurrent episodes of sinusitis and otitis media. The respiratory infections typically have a protracted course but respond to high-dose antibiotic therapy. Pulmonary auscultation shows crackles and wheezing. Cardiovascular examination shows a cardiac point of maximal impulse that is palpated at the right 5th intercostal space. Which of the following is most likely to be dysfunctional in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Dynein arms

questions.text: A patient has a visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the right eye and the perception of light in the left eye. In terms of visual impairment categories, to which category does this individual belong?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Social Blindness

choices.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and re intubate if needed

questions.text: A patient who was on a ventilator for one week suddenly gets agitated and self-extubates himself. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Watch for spontaneous breaths and re intubate if needed

questions.text: A new estrogen receptor agonist is being evaluated for the treatment of postmenopausal symptoms. A prospective study shows that the drug increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in treated women who smoke compared to untreated women who smoke, with a relative risk(RR) of 1.70 and p-value of 0.01. In nonsmokers, no increased risk of DVT is evident with use of the drug (RR = 0.96; p-value = 0.68). Which of the following describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Effect modification

 

This is an example of effect modification (interaction) — the effect of the exposure (estrogen agonist) on the outcome (DVT) varies by levels of another factor (smoking). The association is present in smokers but not in nonsmokers, indicating smoking modifies the drug’s effect rather than being a confounder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. (Confounding): Confounding is a third variable associated with both exposure and outcome that distorts effect estimates; here the differing effect sizes across strata indicate interaction rather than confounding.

 

Option C. (Lead time bias): Related to screening and apparent survival benefit, irrelevant to interaction between exposure and risk factors.

 

Option D. (Observer bias): Systematic measurement bias by the observer; not described by differential RR across subgroups.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Automated External Defibrillator

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is scheduled to undergo a colonoscopy for routine colorectal cancer screening. He has no abdominal pain, gross blood in the stool, constipation, change in stool caliber, or unintentional weight loss. He also has no family history of colon cancer. The procedure is uncomplicated, but the patient is found to have a small mucosal lesion (~1 cm) in his sigmoid colon. The lesion is biopsied and its histology is shown in the image below.

 

 

The pathogenesis of this patient's lesion most likely began with a mutation involving which of the following genes?
questions.solution: Ans. A. APC

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to a 4-week history of a pruritic skin rash. On examination, there are pink papules distributed symmetrically over the anterior surfaces of the shins and ankles. Shave biopsy reveals prominent hyperkeratosis along with a thickened granular layer. In addition, there is a bandlike infiltrate of mononuclear cells in the superficial dermis that involves the overlying epidermis. The rete ridges have a sharpened, sawtooth appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D.﻿﻿﻿ Lichen planus

choices.text: A polygenic disorder with progressive depigmentation.
An autosomal dominant disorder involving the C-kit protooncogene.
An autoimmune condition with progressive depigmentation.
A sporadic condition without a genetic link.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents who are concerned about white patches on her skin that they noticed since childhood. Physical examination is shown below. She mentions that her grandfather had similar patches since his birth. They also report that a cousin on her father's side has been recently diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. Given the patient's history and clinical presentation, which of the following describes the underlying cause of her condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) An autosomal dominant disorder involving the C-kit protooncogene.

questions.text: Identify the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zika virus disease

 

The mosquito in the image is Aedes aegypti, also known as the "tiger mosquito" due to the distinctive white stripes on its body and legs. Aedes aegypti is well-known for its "hunchback" posture when feeding and has a flight range of approximately 100 meters, although it may travel farther under certain conditions. This mosquito species primarily breeds in artificial collections of rainwater, such as in discarded tires, bottles, or containers that collect water during the rainy season.

 

Aedes aegypti is the vector responsible for transmitting several viral diseases, including:

 

  • Zika virus disease
  • Dengue fever
  • Chikungunya fever
  • Yellow fever

 

In this case, the correct answer is Zika virus disease, as it is directly associated with this mosquito species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JE (Japanese Encephalitis): Japanese Encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus, not by Aedes aegypti.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, primarily Anopheles gambiae and Anopheles stephensi in different regions, not by Aedes aegypti.

 

Option D. Lymphatic filariasis: Lymphatic filariasis is transmitted by Culex quinquefasciatus (also known as Culex fatigans) in certain regions, rather than by Aedes aegypti.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Aedes aegypti is the vector responsible for transmitting diseases such as Zika virus, dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever. It is characterized by white stripes on its body and legs and typically breeds in man-made water collections.

choices.text: Prospective cohort study

questions.text: Researchers are studying the relationship between essential hypertension and a common mutation in the structure of a sodium channel protein. A study population is randomly selected and blood samples are obtained for leukocyte genotyping. The prevalence of hypertension is determined based on mean blood pressure measurements obtained using standardized ambulatory blood pressure monitoring conducted over 1 week. Based on the analysis results, the researchers conclude that the sodium channel structure mutation is associated with hypertension. Which of the following best describes the study design used by the investigators?
questions.solution: ﻿Ans. B. Cross-sectional study

questions.text: You are the team leader during a cardiac arrest resuscitation scenario in a hospital setting. A 65-year-old patient has suddenly collapsed and is unresponsive. The monitor displays a rhythm as shown in the image. What is the next immediate step?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Defibrillate at 360 joules

questions.text: What is the nerve blocked in the following local anesthesia technique?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Nasociliary nerve

choices.text: Only the health workers are given Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus toxoid

questions.text: In the aftermath of a natural disaster, a public health team is tasked with implementing a vaccination protocol to prevent outbreaks of infectious diseases among the affected population. Considering the increased risk of certain infections in post-disaster settings, which of the following vaccination strategies is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only the health workers are given Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus toxoid

 

In post-disaster situations, vaccination guidelines prioritize protecting healthcare workers who are at higher risk of exposure due to prolonged contact with affected populations and environmental hazards. For the general population, most vaccines are contraindicated immediately after a disaster because they do not provide rapid immunity, and many infectious diseases have short incubation periods, meaning they may spread before immunity can develop. However, health workers are provided with Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus toxoid vaccinations since they are exposed over a longer term and need added protection to maintain essential health services.

 

The exception to this general rule is the measles vaccine, which can provide faster immunity than the incubation period of the disease. For this reason, measles vaccination may sometimes be administered to prevent outbreaks among the general population in high-risk situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Everyone is given Diphtheria vaccine: The diphtheria vaccine is not typically a priority in post-disaster settings and does not provide immediate protection. It is not included in standard emergency protocols for general population immunization after a disaster.

 

Option B. Everyone is given Tetanus toxoid: Although tetanus toxoid is important, it is not provided universally to everyone after a disaster. Instead, it is prioritized for individuals with wounds at risk of tetanus exposure and healthcare workers who face ongoing risk.

 

 

Option C. Everyone is given Cholera vaccine: The cholera vaccine is contraindicated for the general population after a disaster. Its use is limited to specific outbreak situations and, in this case, is more relevant for healthcare workers who are in contact with patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-disaster settings, Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus toxoid vaccinations are given primarily to health workers, not the general population, as they are most at risk of long-term exposure to these infections.

questions.text:
Identify the correct pair of contraceptive dosages:

 

  1. Ulipristal for emergency contraception-30mg single dose
  2. LNG for emergency contraception 1.5mg two tablets repeated after 12hrs
  3. DMPA 150mg im 3 monthly
  4. Mirena 52mg LNG with 20ug/d release
questions.solution: Ans. C. 1,3,4

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of high-grade fever, altered mental status, and severe respiratory distress. His family reports that he recently attended a wedding in a rural area of Kozhikode district of Kerala, where he consumed freshly tapped toddy (tapped from the sap of palm trees), a local drink. Over the next day, three more individuals from the same wedding presented with similar symptoms. On examination, the patient appears lethargic, disoriented, with reduced chest sounds on the right side. His CSF analysis reveals an elevated protein count with normal glucose and an decrease in lymphocytes. Given the clinical presentation and his recent history, which of the following infectious agents is most likely responsible for this outbreak?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus 

 

Nipah virus infection is associated with outbreaks in certain regions, particularly in Kerala, India. Kozhikode district has previously reported cases of Nipah virus, which can be transmitted through the consumption of contaminated fruit or beverages such as freshly tapped toddy (palm sap) contaminated by bats. Key clinical features include high-grade fever, altered mental status, and respiratory distress, which align with the symptoms in this case. CSF analysis showing elevated protein with normal glucose is consistent with viral infections such as Nipah, and the decrease in lymphocytes is also compatible with viral involvement.

 

Nipah virus can cause encephalitis and severe respiratory symptoms, leading to high mortality in clusters, which explains the similar symptoms among others at the wedding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hantavirus: Typically associated with rodent exposure and causes Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome, which is less likely in this geographic and clinical context.

 

Option C. Zika virus: Zika primarily causes mild febrile illness and is linked to congenital defects; severe respiratory and neurological symptoms are uncommon.

 

Option D. West Nile virus: West Nile virus can cause encephalitis but is not typically associated with this clinical pattern or the region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus is an emerging zoonotic infection with potential for outbreaks in regions like Kerala, especially linked to consumption of contaminated fruit or palm sap.

choices.text: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done.
High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used.
It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.

questions.solution: Ans. C. It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.

questions.text: 26-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to a skin condition. The patient has had dry, flaky skin since childhood, but it has worsened in recent years. Symptoms are typically worse in the winter but improve as the weather warms. The patient has a family history of asthma; both parents also have chronically dry skin. Examination is shown below. Which of the following is most likely contributing to this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C.﻿﻿﻿ Defective keratinocyte desquamation

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia comes to the emergency department of medical center with chest pain, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis. An electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevation in the anterior leads, and cardiac enzymes are markedly elevated. Investigators at the center are designing a randomized control trial to test the hypothesis that drug B will decrease the mortality associated with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction compared to standard of care. To ensure that investigators will not miss a difference between drug B and standard of care (if a difference truly exists), which of the following would they want to maximize?
questions.solution: Ans. D) ﻿﻿﻿1-beta

These cells demonstrate some myeloid surface markers and can interact closely with T lymphocytes. The cells described above are best referred to as which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. B. ﻿﻿﻿Langerhans cells

Check responsiveness, Verify scene safety, start chest compressions

questions.solution: Ans. B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, Defibrillate when available

Sentinel surveillance relies on passive case finding.
Sentinel surveillance is done in OPD of health centres.

questions.solution: Ans. D. Sentinel surveillance includes finding hidden or missing cases of diseases.

questions.text:
Identify the true statements:

 

  1. Glycopyrrolate is used as an anti-sialagogue prior to surgery
  2. Duration of action of proparacaine is 15-20 minutes
  3. Thermodilution method using Fick Principle can be used to estimate the dead space volume
  4. Most common cause for delayed discharge from hospital post day care surgery is Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)
questions.solution: Ans. B. 1,2,4

questions.text: Sustainable development goals (SDGs) are under which health organization?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) UNDP

 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are a global framework adopted by the United Nations, aiming for significant improvements in social, economic, and environmental aspects worldwide by 2030. These goals are managed and promoted primarily by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), which works closely with other UN bodies and governments to implement the goals.

 

The SDGs encompass 17 broad goals, with one specifically health-related goal:

 

  • Goal 3: Ensure health and well-being for all, which includes important targets such as reducing the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR), Under-5 Mortality Rate, and Neonatal Mortality Rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UNICEF: Although UNICEF supports child health and development programs globally, it does not oversee the SDGs. Its focus aligns with specific SDG targets, particularly those related to children and maternal health, but it is not responsible for managing the SDGs.

 

Option B. UNFPA: The United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) primarily focuses on reproductive health, family planning, and population issues. While UNFPA contributes to the achievement of certain SDG targets, it is not the lead agency for the SDGs.

 

Option D. WHO: The World Health Organization (WHO) is a key player in achieving health-related SDG targets, especially those under Goal 3. However, WHO is not responsible for managing the SDGs; it focuses on providing technical support and health guidelines globally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) is the primary organization responsible for managing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

choices.text: Crypt abscesses in colonic mucosa
IgG-mediated skin disruption
Increased intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a 2-month history of a pruritic rash as shown below. The patient has been using skin emollients, but the lesions have not improved. Skin examination shows a papulovesicular skin rash in groups with erosion and excoriations. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. ﻿﻿﻿Increased intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes

questions.text: A screening test is positive in 50% diseased population and 10% healthy population. Calculate the PPV:
questions.solution: Ans. A. 83

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman who is planning to start a family visits your clinic for preconception counseling. She is a healthcare worker and is concerned about her risk of exposure to various infections. She has received most standard vaccinations. She asks for your advice on vaccinations she should consider before becoming pregnant. Which of the following vaccines should you advise her to avoid receiving now, as she is planning for pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella vaccine

 

Women planning for pregnancy should avoid live vaccines before conception because live attenuated vaccines, such as the varicella vaccine, pose a theoretical risk of transmission to the fetus. Live vaccines can interact with the immunosuppressed state of pregnancy, potentially affecting fetal development.

 

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and WHO recommend that women avoid conception for at least three months after receiving a live vaccine such as varicella, as well as MMR (measles, mumps, rubella). If a live vaccine has been administered, it’s advised to delay pregnancy to minimize any potential risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A vaccine: This is an inactivated (killed) vaccine and is safe to administer prior to or during pregnancy if needed.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B vaccine: This is a recombinant vaccine, safe to administer during preconception and pregnancy as it does not contain live components.

 

Option C. Rabies vaccine: This vaccine is also an inactivated vaccine and is safe for preconception and pregnancy, especially given that rabies is a fatal disease if untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines, such as varicella and MMR, should be avoided for at least three months before conception. If already taken, women are advised to delay pregnancy to reduce any potential risks to fetal development.

choices.text: Analysis of variance

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the relationship between smoking status and forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1). Subjects are randomly selected and categorized based on smoking status. Group A consists of 200 nonsmokers, group B consists of 200 light smokers (1-7 cigarettes per day), group C consists of 200 moderate smokers (8-22 cigarettes per day), and group D consists of 200 heavy smokers (23+ cigarettes per day). FEV1 is quantitatively measured in all participants using properly calibrated office spirometers. Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical method to compare the mean FEV1 results among all 4 groups?
questions.solution: Ans. A. ﻿﻿﻿Analysis of variance

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

questions.text: A 25-year-old previously healthy man comes to the OPD due to penile lesions. The patient first noticed a nontender papule on his penis a month ago, and it has progressively increased in size and number. He reports no fever, dysuria, or penile discharge. There are no enlarged inguinal lymph nodes. Treatment is started with a topical agent that acts as a toll-like receptor agonist to increase antiviral cytokine production. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. ﻿﻿﻿Imiquimod

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2 at 28 weeks is brought to the emergency after being found unconscious at home by her mother. She is disoriented on arrival and her BP is 180/110 mmHg and 4 + proteinuria. On arrival at the emergency, she has a tonic-clonic seizure which resolves with MgSO4 administration. Once the patient is stabilized, she undergoes caesarean delivery for fetal distress. Post-partum, the below MRI is done. What is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

 

  • The case is classic for eclampsia: pregnant woman with hypertension, proteinuria, seizures.
  • The MRI shows bilateral symmetrical areas of hyperintensity in the posterior cerebral hemispheres (parieto-occipital regions), most characteristic of PRES.
  • PRES is associated with eclampsia and presents with headache, altered mental status, seizures, and visual disturbances. MRI usually shows vasogenic edema—seen as high signal in posterior regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hematoma, Option B. Parenchymal hemorrhage, Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Would show focal or diffuse hyperintensity in different locations, not typically as bilateral posterior edema.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to blisters on his trunk and groin. Itching has occurred for the past several weeks, and blisters developed a week ago. He has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. The patient received the zoster vaccine at age 60. Examination shows numerous 0.5- to 3-cm bullous skin lesions. The findings from a skin biopsy are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Bullous pemphigoid

choices.text: Prospective cohort study
Retrospective cohort study

questions.text: 400 women aged 20-35 coming for routine check-up are asked about their smoking status. 40% of the women are smokers. Over the next ten years, 25 smokers and 24 non-smokers developed breast cancer. Which of the following best describes the study design?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Prospective cohort study

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. The commonly used frequency of tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring is 50 Hz.

  2. The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

  3. Lorazepam can be used as an intravenous induction agent

  4. drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery is Cefazolin
questions.solution: Ans. A. 1,2,3,4

choices.text: Langerhans cell histiocytosis

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his mother due to a rash that started 3 days ago. A similar red, itchy rash on the cheeks, trunk, and arms has occurred intermittently since infancy. The mother had thought that the rashes were related to the consumption of certain foods, but elimination of cow's milk and fruits did not improve the rash. The patient has had a few upper respiratory infections but no major illnesses. Vaccinations are up to date, and he takes no medications. The diaper area is clear, and no mucosal lesions are present. This patient's current condition increases his risk of developing which of the following additional disorders?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Asthma

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In line manual stabilization

 

The maneuver being performed is in-line manual stabilization of the cervical spine. This is used in trauma cases to prevent any movement of the head and neck, minimizing the risk of spinal cord injury until definitive immobilization (like a cervical collar) is applied.

 

  • Both hands support the patient’s head and neck in a neutral position.
  • There’s no attempt to extend, flex, tilt, or rotate the neck.
  • This technique is crucial in suspected cervical spine injuries during transfers, airway management, or evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head tilt, chin lift:

 

  • The most common basic airway opening technique for unconscious patients without suspected cervical spine injury.
  • The head is tilted backward and the chin lifted upward to open the airway by moving the tongue away from the posterior pharynx.

 

Option B. Jaw thrust:

 

  • Airway maneuver often used when cervical spine injury is suspected.
  • The lower jaw is pushed upward without moving the cervical spine to open the airway.

 

 

Option C. Head extension:

 

  • This is simply moving the head backward to extend the neck.
  • It helps open the airway but can harm patients with cervical spine injury.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 1-day history of skin rash. Two weeks ago, she had an episode of recurrent genital lesions, which began with small papules and subsequently became vesicular with ulceration, crusting, and eventual healing. On physical examination, she appears comfortable. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Skin findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythema multiforme

 

Erythema multiforme (EM) is an acute, immune-mediated condition often triggered by infections, most commonly Herpes simplex virus. It presents with target lesions (concentric rings with a central dusky zone), typically involving extremities and sometimes mucosa. Patients are usually stable and afebrile. EM is self-limiting, and management involves treating the underlying cause (e.g., suppressive antiviral therapy for HSV). This patient’s recent genital herpes followed by target lesions is a classic sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated herpes simplex infection: Presents with systemic illness, fever, diffuse vesiculopustular lesions, and potential visceral involvement. This patient is stable, afebrile, and has target lesions, not diffuse vesicles.

 

Option C. Primary HIV infection: Manifests with flu-like illness, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular rash, not with target lesions linked to recent HSV reactivation.

 

Option D. Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS): A severe mucocutaneous reaction often triggered by drugs, with fever, systemic symptoms, and widespread epidermal necrosis. Unlike EM, SJS has extensive mucosal involvement and systemic toxicity.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery, and the anesthesia team needs to ensure the proper connection of the oxygen supply. Which of the following PIN (Pin-Index) configurations corresponds to the oxygen supply in medical gas cylinders?
questions.solution: Ans. B. 2,5

questions.text: There is a nuclear family consisting of a married couple and their two children. There is a spacing of 4 years between the births of children. Which phase of the Family Cycle is characterized by the first child moving out of the home of his/her parents?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Contraction

 

The Family Life Cycle has several stages, each defined by specific family events. The Contraction phase begins when the first child leaves the parental home. This phase reflects the beginning of the family's shift from an extended family structure to a smaller, contracted form as children begin to move out.

 

The stages in the Family Life Cycle are typically defined as follows:

 

  • Formation: From marriage until the birth of the first child.
  • Extension: From the birth of the first child to the birth of the last child.
  • Completed Extension: From the birth of the last child until the first child leaves home.
  • Contraction: From the time the first child leaves home until the last child leaves.
  • Complete Contraction: From the time the last child leaves home until the death of one spouse.
  • Dissolution or Extinction: From the death of one spouse until the death of the surviving spouse.

 

The family enters the Contraction phase when the first child moves out of the home.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Contraction phase in the Family Life Cycle begins when the first child leaves the parental home.

questions.text: 61-year-old woman comes to the physician with a skin bumps on her trunk, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) ﻿﻿﻿Renal failure

questions.text: Identify the laryngeal mask airway from the picture below?

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled intention-to-treat clinical trial of a new drug for the treatment of peripheral neuropathy in adults with multiple myeloma (MM). One hundred fifty patients with MM are enrolled in the trial and randomized to receive either the new drug (n = 75) or placebo (n = 75). Trial protocol requires that patients in both groups take 1 pill per day and keep a pain diary. After 3 months of treatment, each patient is interviewed, and the pain diaries are reviewed; 9 patients taking the new drug and 3 patients taking placebo did not take the pills as instructed. Which of the following best describes how the data pertaining to all patients who did not adhere to protocol should be treated?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Keep all 12 nonadherent patients in their respective groups for analysis

questions.text: A 24-year-old young truck driver has developed a fissure in ano. What would be the ideal anesthesia for this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Saddle anesthesia

 

Saddle anesthesia is ideal for procedures involving the perineal area, such as fissure in ano, as it provides anesthesia to the areas in contact with a saddle (perineum, buttocks, inner thighs) while allowing the patient to remain awake and maintain control over their upper body. It is a targeted form of spinal anesthesia that limits the anesthetic effect to the lower pelvis and perineal region.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudal anesthesia: Caudal anesthesia, administered through the sacral hiatus, can also anesthetize the lower perineal area but is more commonly used in pediatric patients and may provide a broader block than necessary for a simple anal fissure procedure in adults.

 

Option B. Epidural anesthesia: Epidural anesthesia provides a broader area of anesthesia and may be more invasive than required for this minor procedure. It is often reserved for longer or more extensive surgeries or cases where postoperative pain control is essential.

 

Option D. Spinal anesthesia: While spinal anesthesia can be used, it often results in a more extensive block than needed for an anal fissure procedure. Saddle anesthesia specifically targets the perineal area, reducing unnecessary anesthesia to other regions.

 

Educational Objective:


Saddle anesthesia is the preferred choice for procedures involving the perineum, like fissure in ano, as it provides targeted anesthetic coverage to the relevant area without affecting the entire lower body.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to poor feeding, irritability, and rash. questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the OPD due to skin lesions on his back. He first noted the spots 5 years ago and says they are becoming more numerous. The lesions are occasionally pruritic but are otherwise asymptomatic. Medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seborrehic keratosis

 

The likely diagnosis is A. Seborrheic keratosis. The image shows multiple, well-circumscribed, waxy, stuck-on, hyperpigmented papules and plaques, which are characteristic of seborrheic keratoses. Seborrheic keratoses are benign skin lesions that often appear in older adults and increase in number over time; they may be pruritic but are otherwise asymptomatic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actinic keratosis: presents as rough, scaly plaques on sun-exposed areas and is considered premalignant, not as "stuck-on" warty lesions.

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis versicolor: presents as hypo- or hyperpigmented patches with fine scale.

 

 

Option D. Acanthosis nigricans: shows velvety, hyperpigmented thickening of flexural surfaces, not discrete raised plaques

choices.text: Strategies, Tactics, and Evaluation Plan for RTA accidents
Surveillance, Training, and Emergency Preparedness for Disasters
Stepwise, Tool-based, and Evidence-informed policy for Measles

questions.text: What is the use of Stepwise approach of WHO in the context of public health interventions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NCD risk factor surveillance

 

The Stepwise approach developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) is specifically used for Non-Communicable Disease (NCD) risk factor surveillance. This approach is designed to collect standardized data on NCD risk factors in a population, allowing for monitoring trends and informing public health policies.

 

The WHO Stepwise approach involves:

 

  1. Questionnaire-based assessment: Collecting data on behavioral risk factors such as tobacco use, alcohol consumption, and diet.
  2. Physical measurements: Taking anthropometric measurements like height, weight, and blood pressure.
  3. Biochemical measurements: Blood samples for glucose, cholesterol, etc., to assess metabolic risk factors.

 

This approach is used globally to gather data for the prevention and control of NCDs by identifying modifiable risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strategies, Tactics, and Evaluation Plan for RTA accidents: This is not relevant to the WHO Stepwise approach, which is specifically focused on NCD surveillance.

 

Option C. Surveillance, Training, and Emergency Preparedness for Disasters: The Stepwise approach is not used for disaster preparedness or emergency response.

 

Option D. Stepwise, Tool-based, and Evidence-informed policy for Measles: This is unrelated as the approach is focused on NCDs, not infectious diseases like measles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO Stepwise approach is a tool for surveillance of non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factors, using standardized methods to collect behavioral, physical, and biochemical data.

choices.text: The magnitude of systolic BP and serum cholesterol levels are closely related.
A patient with a high systolic BP is likely to have high serum cholesterol.
A patient with a low systolic BP is likely to have low serum cholesterol.
80% of the variation in BP can be explained by serum cholesterol and vice versa.

questions.text: A group of researchers found a correlation coefficient of 0.90 (p-value = 0.01) between the systolic BP and serum cholesterol levels of patients attending their clinics. Which of the following statements is an incorrect interpretation of this study?
questions.solution: Ans. A. The magnitude of systolic BP and serum cholesterol levels are closely related.

questions.text: The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Spinal anesthesia

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a persistent skin rash. He has a 6-month history of a scaly rash involving the upper and lower extremities that is associated with mild pruritus. Medical history is notable for childhood asthma and orolabial herpes simplex virus infection. On examination, the patient has skin lesions as shown in the image below. This patient's disorder is most likely associated with which of the following extradermal complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deforming joint disease

 

This patient’s history and the image are classic for plaque psoriasis, an immune-mediated chronic skin disorder. The most significant extradermal (systemic) complication of psoriasis is psoriatic arthritis, which can lead to a deforming joint disease. Psoriasis is frequently associated with joint involvement: about 30% of patients will develop psoriatic arthritis, which can be deforming and disabling if untreated. The arthritis presents as joint pain, swelling, and can lead to permanent deformities, affecting fingers, toes (dactylitis), and the spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic glomerulonephritis: is not a typical complication of psoriasis . Although some studies show an increased risk of chronic kidney disease and glomerulonephritis in severe psoriasis, it is not a common or direct complication. The association often relates to comorbidities (e.g., diabetes, hypertension) or drug-related nephrotoxicity.

 

Option C. Medullary thyroid cancer: is linked to MEN syndromes, not psoriasis because this cancer arises from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid and is primarily linked with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) type 2 genetic mutations, which are associated with Mucosal Neuromas

 

Option D. Pulmonary fibrosis: is associated with other connective tissue and autoimmune diseases, not psoriasis because fibrotic lung disease principally occurs in systemic sclerosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and lupus rather than psoriasis. Psoriasis-related lung involvement is rare.

 

Systemic Manifestations of Psoriasis:

 

  1. Arthritis (Psoriatic arthritis, ~30%) – asymmetric oligoarthritis, DIP involvement, arthritis mutilans, axial disease.
  2. Nail changes – pitting, onycholysis, subungual hyperkeratosis, oil-drop sign.
  3. Ocular involvement – anterior uveitis, conjunctivitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca.
  4. Metabolic syndrome & cardiovascular risk – obesity, diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypertension, ↑ MI/stroke.
  5. Other organ associations – inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn’s), NAFLD, chronic kidney disease.
  6. Psychiatric manifestations – depression, anxiety, social withdrawal.

questions.text: A 50-year-old historian is researching the impact of medical advancements on society. He notes a significant shift in the leading causes of mortality from infectious to chronic diseases over the past century. This observation is crucial for understanding how public health strategies have evolved. What term best describes this shift in disease prevalence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epidemiological transition

 

The epidemiological transition refers to the shift in the pattern of disease prevalence from infectious diseases, which were the leading causes of mortality in earlier centuries, to chronic, non-communicable diseases (NCDs) such as heart disease, cancer, and diabetes, which now predominate in more developed countries. This transition is closely linked to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and socio-economic development, which reduce the burden of infectious diseases.

 

However, in countries like India, both communicable and non-communicable diseases remain significant, a phenomenon called the dual burden of disease. While infectious diseases like tuberculosis and malaria are still common, the rates of chronic diseases have also risen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paradoxical transition: This is not a recognized term in epidemiology for describing the shift in disease patterns from infectious to non-communicable diseases.

 

Option B. Reversal of transition: This term does not apply in this context, as it suggests a backward shift, whereas the change described is a forward progression in public health.

 

Option D. Demographic transition: The demographic transition refers to changes in population dynamics, particularly the shift from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as a country develops. While related to epidemiology, this term is more focused on population structure rather than disease patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The term epidemiological transition best describes the shift in the leading causes of mortality from infectious to chronic diseases, a trend observed in more developed countries as public health strategies improve over time.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19 develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive but is breathing rapidly. Sp02 is measured to be 86%. He is administered oxygen via a face mask with a reservoir bag with a flow rate of 10 L/min. After a trial of one hour, his Sp02 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. B. High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

choices.text: Koilocytosis of the superficial epidermal layers

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the OPD with a 4-day history of severe left-sided chest discomfort. The pain is constant and has a burning quality. Over the last day, the patient has developed a rash in the area of discomfort. He has not had similar symptoms before. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be found in the affected area?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ﻿﻿﻿Multinucleated cells with intranuclear inclusions

 

The clinical scenario is classic for Herpes Zoster (shingles) caused by reactivation of latent Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) in dorsal root ganglia. Patients first experience burning neuropathic pain in a dermatomal distribution, followed by the appearance of grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. On histopathology, VZV produces multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions (Cowdry type A bodies). A Tzanck smear from the base of the vesicle can reveal these cells. This cytopathic effect is shared with HSV, but the clinical presentation here strongly supports shingles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acantholysis and intercellular IgG deposits:

 

  • This describes pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by antibodies against desmoglein.
  • Histology shows loss of intercellular connections (acantholysis) and a “fish-net” pattern of IgG on immunofluorescence.
  • Not related to a dermatomal painful rash.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions: 

 

  • These are typical of poxyvirus infections, e.g., molluscum contagiosum, where large intracytoplasmic inclusions (Henderson–Patterson bodies) are seen.
  • Lesions appear as umbilicated papules, not painful grouped vesicles.

 

Option C. Koilocytosis of the superficial epidermal layers: 

 

  • Koilocytes are squamous epithelial cells with perinuclear halos and nuclear atypia seen in HPV infections (e.g., verruca vulgaris, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia).
  • HPV causes warts, not painful dermatomal vesicular eruptions.

questions.text: What is the dose and route of the birth dose of BCG vaccine?
questions.solution: Ans. D) 0.05ml intra-dermal

questions.text: Which of the following methods provides the most complete evaluation of protein quality?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Net protein utilization

questions.text: Research is being conducted to assess the nutritional status of the children in a particular district. For this purpose, 2 children are randomly selected from every school in the district. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cluster

 

Schools act as clusters, and children are sampled within them. This reduces cost and logistics in large populations and is a standard method for community health surveys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random: requires selecting children directly from the whole district, not grouped by schools.

 

Option B. Systematic random: involves fixed intervals (e.g., every 5th child), not cluster-based.

 

Option C. Stratified random: divides population into strata (e.g., age or gender groups) before random selection, unlike clustering by schools.

questions.text: All of the following are used as an anti-larval measure in mosquito control programs except:

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to worsening left lower extremity pain, swelling, and redness over the past 3 days. The patient has had no trauma but reports feeling feverish. Medical history is significant for hypertension and obesity. Physical examination shows diffuse erythema extending up to the left midcalf with indistinct border. There is increased warmth, tenderness, and edema of the left leg. No areas of fluctuation or purulent exudate are present, but the interdigital skin of the feet is macerated and fissured. Laboratory testing shows neutrophilic leukocytosis, and Doppler ultrasonography is negative for deep venous thrombosis. Infection with which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Beta-hemolytic streptococci
